In 1988-1990, the facility was modernized and upgraded once more, and while designed for production of up to 32 mgd it currently operates at a maximum of 32 mgd by a permit granted by the California Department of Public Health in 1998 the WTP replaced its on-site 6 million gallon reservoir. The system for handling chlorine was installed during the 1988-1990 modernization. 
 
Chlorine is used at the WTP to disinfect raw water drawn from the Contra Costa Canal or from wells operated by the City.  Chlorine is typically packaged as a liquefied gas under pressure in steel containers. One ton cylinders of Chlorine are used at the WTP, thus exceeding the 2500-pound threshold amount set by the EPA, 1500 pounds set by OSHA and the 100-pound limit set by the State of California.
 
The limits of the processes include all the equipment, facilities and procedures to handle chlorine while it is under pressure.  Once chlorine reaches the mixing equipment, it is no longer in concentrations that would make it hazardous and pose little risk to workers and no risk to the public.
 
Specific quantities handled and details of the systems are included in the details of the applicable compliance submittals to both EPA and Contra Costa County.
i-4  Worst Case Release Scenario
As required by both EPA and California regulations, the City has evaluated the worst case scenario for chlorine using parameters mandated in those regulations.  The City's limiting worst-case scenario is the rupture of one chlorine cylinder and the loss of the entire contents over at 10-minute period.  The distance to the toxic endpoint was determined using tables and equations provided by the EPA. 
 
The chlorine liquid release is assumed to form a 1 cm pool from which evaporation takes place.  The entire pool is estimated to evaporate over 10 minutes.  The released quantity has not been assumed to be limited by any controls.  The EPA as a part of this analysis mandates a c

tial to cause a release of hazardous materials.  The WTP is designed and operated in such a way as to minimize the probability and the impact of such events.  Events and preventions considered in the design and operation of the facility include, but are not limited to: security, temperature extremes, earthquakes, winds, excessive precipitation, utility disruption, and wildland fires.  
 
Of particular interest, given its California location, is earthquake susceptibility.  The hazardous materials area of the WTP was completely revamped in the late 1980's and includes the best ground motion technology available.  Additionally, the WTP is on solid ground which limits the severity of ground motion.  The WTP has conducted independent assessments of risks associated with lateral ground motion. Although there will be damage to equipment from a worst credible earthquake, studies have indicated that catastrophic loss of containment should not be a concern.  The specifics of the analysis are detailed in section 6.2.3.

i-6.2  Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The prevention programs described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. Many of these prevention programs (e.g., PHA's, compliance audits, incident investigations) result in the development and implementation of additional safeguards (administrative and engineering controls). Those recommendations that are planned for implementation are discussed in Planned Changes to Improve Safety. Those applicable safeguards that have already been implemented or that were part of the original design are summarized below and d

escribed in more detail in section 6.2.5. These safeguards prevent, detect, or mitigate accidental releases of regulated substances.
 
All covered processes have control systems designed to maintain operating parameters (temperature, pressures, flow, level, etc.) within allowable limits. The covered processes are also equipped with alarms to alert personnel when the operating parameters exceed the allowable limits. The stationary source developed procedures and conducts training of personnel to familiarize them with the consequences of exceeding allowable limits (safety and operability) to ensure the correct response to these alarms. The following summarizes chemical-specific safeguards that exist at the stationary source and are presented in more detail in the Process Hazard Analysis section of the Plan.
 
	Release Detection
Chlorine monitor / detector
Pressure monitors in Control House
WTP staffing and surveillance 24 hours per day
Additional staffing for material handling operations during daylight hours
 
 
	Release Containment/Control 
Automatic activation of scrubber to prevent Chlorine release outside a containment building
Process relief valves to prevent catastrophic release from inadvertent overpressure
Valves to permit isolation of the materials form potential leaks
Curbing to contain liquid releases and reduce vaporization
Redundant equipment and instrumentation 
 
	Release Mitigation
Fire suppression and extinguishing systems for Chlorine building
Trained emergency response personnel
Personal protective equipment including self-contained breathing apparatus
Tight building enclosure for Chlorine
Backup generators for power interruption
 
Planned Activities to Improve Safety (from non-technical studies)
It is the intention of the CPWTP to implement all identified improvements to safety, these improvements may originate in both technical (seismic Assessment, PHA, SVA, etc.) and non-technical (Compliance Audits, Incident Investigat

ions, etc.). However, if a situation arises where conflicting planned improvements would make implementation unreasonable (e.g., planned improvements on a process slated for removal from the facility) the facility will state the reasoning for non-implementation in the comments/notes section of each individual study. Each planned improvement to the process may generate from a wide range of both technical and non-technical studies, thus the criteria (including assumptions and interpretations) will be developed on a case-by-case basis, as best applicable to the planned improvement under review and utilizing applicable industry standards and best practices.
 
 
i-6.3  Prevention Program Summary
The WTP has taken the necessary steps to comply with the Accidental Release Prevention program requirements set forth under OSHA, EPA and State process safety regulations.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place.
 
Process Safety Information
The WTP maintains a record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.  This information is important for conducting hazard studies, ensuring adequate facility modification, and providing effective training for WTP personnel.  Process Safety Information is described in more detail in Section 6.1.
 
Process Hazard Analysis
The WTP conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the covered processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is a HAZOP study. Findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The WTP performed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) with the objective to identify hazards, identify credible human errors and/or equipment failures that could lead to an accidental release. The most recent PHA/update was performed on January 24, 2017. The PHA and its results are descri

bed in more detail in Section 6.2.
 
There was also a detailed seismic assessment conducted in April, 2016. This seismic hazards review was conducted in accordance with the guidance document for CalARP seismic assessments approved by the Region I Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). A seismic walkdown in which a physical inspection of components is performed to verify the existence and condition of features designed to secure or mitigate process hazards due to seismic activity is required.  A summary of the seismic assessment including the methodology, performance objectives, discussion of the site relative to known active faults and site specific seismic concerns is available in Section 6.2.3 of the RMP. A report further detailing the methodology used as well as the findings from the seismic assessment is available for review behind Tab F of the CPWTP Process Safety Management binder, maintained in the WTP control room.
 
Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, the WTP maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. A Certification of Procedures form is maintained within the CPWTP Process Safety Management binder. Procedures are reviewed annually by the Operations Supervisor. The Certification form is signed and dated by the Operations Supervisor after the review session. The form includes an Appendix A that lists the procedures reviewed as well as the locations of the procedures. 
 
The CPWTP has policies in place governing the development of operating procedures and safe work practices. Typically changes to equipment that would require updates/changes to operating procedures are designated via the facility MOC

process. Operating Procedures recognized as needing to be updated, either through the MOC process, or through suggestions from personnel operating on the regulated process (as part of the Employee Participation program), are required to go through the following steps:
Operations Supervisor/Superintendent are given details of the proposed changes, these details are to include:
Description of existing procedure/safe work practice to be changed
Equipment and/or processes affected by the change
Reason for the change
The Operations Supervisor/Superintendent will review the proposed changes with all affected personnel (operations and maintenance) and elicit feedback as to the efficacy as well as hazards that may develop as a result of the change (Note: that the need for a Process Hazard Analysis will be determined as part of the MOC process associated with the change).
Written Operating Procedures/Safe Work Practices detailing the specific procedures will be developed by the Operations Supervisor/Superintendent or authorized designee.
Updated written procedures will be added to the CPWTP Operations Plan.
Any procedures considered out-of-date as a result of the change will be removed from the operations plan.
 
For more information regarding Operating Procedures, refer to section 6.3 Operating Procedures. Employee participation in the development of operating procedures is described in Section 6.10 Employee Participation.
 
Training
The WTP has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating and maintaining the processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed. Training programs are described in more detail in Section 6.4.
 
Mechanical Integrity
The WTP carries out maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes: emergency scrubber, one

roperty damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.
 
i-8  Emergency Response Plan
To ensure proper functionality, the facility's emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the Plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the covered processes that would require a modified emergency response.
 
The City participates in the Contra Costa County Community Warning System, allowing for communication and notification. The CCHS, in conjunction with Contra Costa County Community Awareness & Emergency Response (CCCCAER), has developed the Community Warning System (CWS) which can be implemented in the event of a release that affects offsite populations. The CWS includes sirens, including one that is located at the WTP, emergency responders are connected through a computer and radio system, the system can activate the EAS, the NWS NOAA Weather Radios, page emergency responders, update information to the media and through the internet, and includes a telephone ring down system. The Community Warning System provides for on-going community outreach to educate the public about the most effective response (usually shelter-in-place) when the sirens sound. 
 
i-9  Continuous Efforts to Improve Safety
Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the Accidental Release Prevention Program. There is a commitment to continue to improve safety by reviewing, revising, and enhancing written procedures as well as implementing other action items. The CPWTP has removed the Anhydrous Ammonia system and replaced it with an inherently safer Liquid Ammonium Sulfate system. None of the action items resulting from the 2017 Chlorine System PHA are critical or essential, rather they represent enhancements or continuous improvement.  
 
i-10  External Events Analysis (CalARP Only)
The WTP is subject to potential external events, which have the poten

-ton chlorine cylinders, piping systems, relief and vent systems, leak detectors and controls. Qualified personnel, who have received previous training in maintenance practices, carry out maintenance operations. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. Mechanical Integrity elements are described in more detail in Section 6.5.
 
Management of Change
Written procedures will be used at the WTP to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification. Management of Change elements are described in more detail in Section 6.6.
 
Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted at the WTP.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. Pre-startup reviews are described in more detail in Section 6.7.
 
Compliance Audits
The WTP conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the Process Safety Regulations are being implemented.  These audits are carried out periodically and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. Compliance Audits are described in more detail in Section 6.8.
 
Incident Investigation
The WTP promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from r

eoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years. Incident Investigations are described in more detail in Section 6.9.
 
Employee Participation
The WTP believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the Process Safety regulations, including information resulting from Process Hazard Analyses. Employee Participation is described in more detail in Section 6.10.
 
Hot Work Permit Program
Pertinent personnel are notified when hot work (i.e., any spark-producing operation including grinding, burning, welding, brazing) is to be performed in a unit and they assure that appropriate safety precautions are taken prior to initiation of the work.  The Hot Work Permit satisfies all of the requirements of Cal OSHA Regulations. Hot Work Permits and procedures are described in more detail in Section 6.11.
 
Contractors
On occasion, the WTP hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, an evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out. The WTP has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the covered processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. This practice is described in more detail in Section 6.12.
 
i-7   Five-Year Accident History

Executive Summary
i-1  Background
In accordance with regulations detailed in Title 40, Chapter 68, as promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency and Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 of the California Code of Regulations, the City of Pittsburg submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the operations of their Water Treatment Plant (WTP) in Pittsburg California.  The City provides potable water to their service area, which coincides with the city limits.  As a part of this operation, hazardous materials are used to meet the quality demands of our customers and compliance with regulations, which protect the public health.
 
A copy of the Water Treatment Plant's Accidental Release Prevention Program policy is included as Figure 1-1.  This policy addresses the City's commitment to preventing accidental releases and to being prepared to respond in the unlikely event that a release should occur.  This RMP is a summary of the specific programs in place, which are incorporated, and a part of our overall safety efforts.
 
i-2  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policy
The WTP is owned by the City of Pittsburg and is located at 300 Olympia Drive.  It operates as a division of its Water Utilities Department. The City is committed to providing needed services to local residents, businesses and visitors to Pittsburg, and to being a positive influence on the community. This includes respect for the safety of the public and city employees, as well as concern for the environment.
 
The City values its employees' efforts to find safer, more effective and more efficient ways of providing service to the community.  Regular safety meetings are held, and employees are encouraged to look for ways to reduce the risk to the employees, to the community or to the environment through the implementation of new technology and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in the policy and compliance manuals, and the facility mis

The maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 3 ppm chlorine as well as the population impacted and sensitive public receptors is listed in the details of this submittal.
 
The worst-case scenario was developed following EPA regulations and it is not considered to be a likely release scenario for emergency planning.  Historically throughout the chlorine industry, a rupture of one-ton cylinder is rare.  Additionally, EPA mandates that assumed meteorological conditions be the most conservative.  Therefore, the results of this worst-case scenario off-site consequence analysis are extremely conservative.
 
i-5  Alternative Case Scenarios
The WTP, considering the history of operations and the staff's experience as well as the hazards identified in the process hazard analyses (PHA), developed more realistic release scenarios or alternative release scenarios (ARS) based on their knowledge and judgment.  These were first presented in the 1995 Risk Management and Prevention Plan (RMPP).  The American Water Works Association Research Foundation's Compliance Guide and Model Risk Management Program for Water Treatment Plants (AWWA Compliance Guidance) was also used to describe emergency planning scenarios.
 
The currently used Alternative Case Scenario was chosen from the Process Hazard Analysis performed on January 24, 2017.  The details of the scenario, the map of the area of concern, and the sensitive receptors within the vulnerability zone around the City WTP are included in the details of the report.
 
i-6  General Accident Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
i-6.1  Management System
The Pittsburg WTP has developed a management system to plan, organize, implement and control the risk management program elements. This system satisfies the requirements of the regulations, and ensures th

sion statement, which are available to all employees.
 
The WTP also trains and requires all employees to be familiar with the WTP Operations Plan kept on site.  Stationary source safety and environmental programs include the following: regular tailgate talks with all WTP staff present; semi-annual Safety Meetings, periodic Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) training, including refresher courses for all staff at the point a new employee is hired; instruction on handling of chemicals and the use or Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).
 
In addition to the above, all employees receive periodic training in the City's Hazard Communications Policy, including instruction on how to read and understand Safety Data Sheets (SDS) posted at the WTP, and the City's Injury & Illness Prevention Plan (IIPP).
 
In addition, there are regularly scheduled, and unscheduled, safety inspections of all City facilities by the City of Pittsburg Safety Committee. The safety committee involves itself in generalized safety concerns across all City departments, while the Public Works committee specializes in maintenance and operations functions of the maintenance departments.  The Public Works Safety Committee includes both the Water Utilities and Maintenance Services Departments. 
 
The WTP has also conducted studies and implemented safety programs, which are included as a part of its Process Safety Management program.  These include periodic Process Hazard Analysis Studies, seismic analyses and prevention program basics such as Management of Change and Incident Investigation.
